description: From Middle English convenient, from Latin conveniens (“fit, suitable, convenient”), present participle of convenire (“to come together, suit”); see convene and compare covenant.

adjectives.description: convenient (comparative more convenient, superlative most convenient)

entries.meaning: Serving to reduce a difficulty, or accessible with minimum difficulty; expedient.
examples: Fast food might be convenient, but it's also very unhealthy.

entries.meaning: Suspicious due to suiting someone's purposes very well.
examples: How convenient that you caught a cold the night before your essay was due.
Neither filthiness, nor foolish talking, nor jesting, which are not convenient.
